31.01.text: I received my first tooth at the age of two and a half.

36.31.text: This was, by all accounts, particularly late in a child’s development –

41.67.text: and meant that I was also late to be weaned.

51.56.text: I did not enjoy teething so much;

54.89.text: its unpleasantness developed in me a certain disregard for these hard buds erupting from my gums.

61.81.text: I found biting with conviction on firm objects to be of benefit and suitable punishment for the teeth.

68.75.text: I would take to chewing anything I could get my young mandible around.

74.26.text: Surprisingly, my teeth survived this intentional barbarity only to be defeated by an oh-so-sweet sticky toffee apple.

92.32.text: and primary teeth are only present to make way for adult teeth.

99.54.text: and by the age of six and a half,

101.69.text: I had unfortunately now gained a complete and fresh set.

108.60.text: I had no interest in their welfare,

111.20.text: I only had interest in the sugariness that passed them by and settled on my tongue.

118.65.text: My first adult tooth was not a victim to my thoughtlessness but was in fact knocked out.

124.56.text: At eleven years of age, a pre-planned “chance meeting” behind the school resulted in an inconspicuous bicuspid, becoming...

136.32.text: The gap left by this missing tooth was thoroughly explored and enjoyed by my tongue with fond reminiscence.

146.74.text: I reached the age of forty eight continuing to lose teeth;

151.39.text: by then, I had lost enough teeth to begin missing them in my day-to-day mastication of food

158.61.text: even if my tongue was now lavishing in the smoothness of its surrounds.

167.64.text: I lost three more through medical intervention and through necessity, I gained my first set of dentures.

179.88.text: It was only then, presented with the disembodied enamels,

184.36.text: that the full beauty of this substantial link between food, tongue, throat and stomach became apparent.

194.15.text: I began to place the form of the teeth above the function,

198.30.text: vetting and analysing food for potential risk of the teeth falling fowl.

204.43.text: Many foods in fact became avoided... avoided or mashed... filtered, separated and mashed again

213.90.text: all for the sake of keeping my prosthetic teeth pristine.

222.93.text: My fascination with teeth soon began to spread outside the realm of my own and into those of other toothed animals.

231.76.text: I marveled at their efficiency, their specificity.

235.33.text: These wondrous beasts had no need to worry their minds about their teeth.

240.88.text: They were blessed with immaculate design;

244.32.text: I would take inspiration from them.

247.57.text: I began to think about how I could combine these specialist points

252.98.text: that perhaps I could improve on my previous God-given and God-inspired dentures.

259.94.text: I realised the perfect cutting, tearing and mashing tools.

267.98.text: At the age of sixty-two, I separated the species

272.19.text: and sorted the teeth into categories of size and shape.

276.39.text: I gathered my resources and set to work on the construction.

280.94.text: Through my thorough studies, I became convinced that I had come to a combination of interspecies teeth that could not be better matched.

293.25.text: My meticulousness meant that they were not finished swiftly,

299.02.text: but they would be of utmost quality.

305.67.text: In my seventieth, the impressive and fierce set of teeth were complete.

333.55.text: I lost the tip of my tongue.
